#Supplementary Material S`r t1 <- t1 + 1; t1`. Case Study 3: Real data on islands

```{r echo=FALSE}
rnk_best_eur_1 <- read.csv("/Users/xavi_rp/Google Drive/MinBA/minba_20190622_maxnet_balears/rankingBestBuffer.csv", header = TRUE)
names(rnk_best_eur_1) <- gsub("andwidth", "uffer", names(rnk_best_eur_1))

prop_notime_bal <- nrow(rnk_best_eur_1[rnk_best_eur_1$Best_Buffer_NoTime != 10, ])/nrow(rnk_best_eur_1) * 100
prop_time_bal <- nrow(rnk_best_eur_1[rnk_best_eur_1$Best_Buffer_WithTime != 10, ])/nrow(rnk_best_eur_1) * 100

if(prop_notime_bal == prop_time_bal){
  prop_bal <- paste0("(", prop_notime_bal, "%)")
}else{
  prop_bal <- paste0(", both taking into account the execution time (", prop_time_bal, "%) and not doing so (", prop_notime_bal, "%)")
}
```


Besides case studies 1 and 2 presented on the main paper, and to assess *MinBAR* for species inhabiting on islands, we run this case study 3 with real data from the Balearic Islands (Western Mediterranean). 

We modelled the distribution of `r nrow(rnk_best_eur_1)` species on the Balearic Islands (see the list in Table S`r t1`.1), although their native distribution also includes other continental areas. The occurrences were downloaded from Bioatles (http://bioatles.caib.es) using the R package *PreSPickR* [@RN6687]. The function *minba* was run with default parameters (10 buffers, 3 model replicates per buffer and completing the models for all of them). MaxEnt models were fit using *maxnet* [@RN2966] with the default parameters, except for the number of background points. We used 19 climatic variables available from WorldClim [@RN6688] at a resolution of 0.5 arc-minutes. 

Both BI_tot and BI_part for most of the species did not improve very much when increasing the buffers after the first half. Table S`r t1`.2 and Figures S`r t1`.1 show that the best models for most of the species were those fit with only part of their distribution `r prop_bal`. The output graphs produced by *minba* can be seen in Figures S`r t1`.2 to S`r t1`.11. 

These results confirm that *MinBAR* performs equally well for islands than for continental data.
